title: 107_hr635
content: The Act may be cited as the "Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site Act". The Congress finds that certain sites and structures in Pennsylvania represent the heritage of the steel industry in the US. Many buildings in Pennsylvania, such as the United States Steel Homestead Works and the Carrie Furnace complex, are significant historical resources. Despite preservation efforts, these structures may be lost without federal assistance. The purpose of this Act is to ensure the preservation of these historical sites. The Act aims to preserve nationally significant historical and cultural sites for present and future generations. It defines a historic site as the Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site and the Secretary as the Secretary of the Interior. The Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site is defined in the Act, aiming to preserve significant historical and cultural sites for future generations. The Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site is established in Pennsylvania as part of the National Park System. It includes the Battle of Homestead site in Munhall and the Carrie Furnace complex in Swissvale and Rankin. The Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site in Pennsylvania includes approximately 35 acres of land with blast furnaces, ore yard, cast house, blowing engine house, and AC power house. It also encompasses the historic Hot Metal Bridge spanning the Monongahela River. The Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site in Pennsylvania includes 35 acres of land with various historic structures and the Hot Metal Bridge spanning the Monongahela River. Federal law allows the Secretary to acquire additional land for the site. The Secretary may acquire property for the historic site, including land, up to 10 acres for facilities, and personal property for interpretation. The Secretary can administer the historic site in accordance with applicable laws and may enter into cooperative agreements with interested parties. Payments made under these agreements are subject to restrictions to prevent misuse of the project. The Secretary may provide technical assistance for the preservation of historic structures, maintenance of the natural and cultural landscape, and local preservation planning at the historic site. SEC. 6. GENERAL MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant officials, must prepare a general management plan for a historic site within a specified timeframe. The plan must be submitted to Congress upon completion. The bill aims to rename the Homestead Steel Works National Historic Site in Pennsylvania.
